hazard.translation[0].definitions[0].def: something that may be dangerous, or cause accidents or problems
hazard.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: That pile of rubbish is a fire hazard  (=something that is likely to cause a fire).
the health hazard posed by lead in petrol
Polluted water sources are a hazard to wildlife.
hazard.translation[0].definitions[1].def: a risk that cannot be avoided
hazard.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: the economic hazards of running a small farm
Divorce seems to be an occupational hazard for politicians.
hazard.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: The rubbish needs to be removed before it becomes a health hazard.
The unoccupied building was declared a fire hazard.
Protesters claim that the nuclear reactor is a safety hazard.
Cars parked in the wrong places can cause a traffic hazard.
One of the most widespread natural hazards is flooding.
Oil from the tanker caused an environmental hazard.
Lead pipes are a serious hazard to health.
Microwave ovens are a potential hazard if not used properly.
There was concern that overhead power lines could cause a health hazard.
It was not known whether radiation from the weapons posed any hazard to soldiers.
They took steps to eliminate all potential fire hazards.
He led the campaign to recognize and reduce the hazard from radiation in our environment.
hazard.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to say something that is only a suggestion or guess and that might not be correct
hazard.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: $50,000? I don’t know. I’m only hazarding a guess.
hazard.translation[1].definitions[1].def: to risk losing your money, property etc in an attempt to gain something
hazard.translation[2].definitions[0].def: something that may be dangerous, cause problems, accidents etc
hazard.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: There may be other workplaces with similar fire hazards.
We want to take waste away from places where it poses a health hazard.
The plant posed serious environmental hazards.
